description:
This is my second time coming for breakfast here. Both times I've had the Damn Cup of coffee and the French Toast. Oh man, the French toast! Bits of dark chocolate that melt slowly... so good! The coffee is very nice as well. 

I plan to return here for the same order every time I'm in the area!
author: Josh L.

description:
Not sure what's been going on recently, but I've been super unlucky and have been finding random things in my food.

Today was a rubber band in the potatoes from Picnic.
author: Shirley H.

description:
Wow this place is really good. Picnic on Third serves comfort-style food crafted in unique ways.

There's good news and great news depending on how you dine here. If you are one of the many MealPal patrons that frequent this place, the 20 meal plan gets you a very healthy portion of a protein (usually chicken) and a side for less than six dollars! If you just order the standard meals, you'll get two large sides of you choice plus the protein and personally I find this option to be way too much food. Those people who complain that the MealPal portions are too small are clearly used to eating at Chipotle or something for lunch because it's more than enough.

I've had a bunch of different dishes here. I think my favorites have been chicken that has featured a mustard dressing of some sort but honestly all of them have been really good. They have plenty of great veggies every day but personally I'm partial to their broccoli and brussle sprouts.

What's not to like? The space is pretty plain. You're not going to want to hang out here and chill out. Recently with Mealpal they switched from "veggie of your choice" to a pre-ordained option which is kind of a bummer because a lot of us have dietary restrictions where we were relying on Picnic for veggie options, and now they often have rice a couple of times a week (not to mention root veggies like carrots) which can be off limits for some people.

All in all, a great place for breakfast and particularly lunch. Recommended!
author: Matt M.

description:
I hate to give this place 3 stars because food is it's really excellent most of the time but I find their portions to be all over the map. Most of the veggies are overcooked. Meat is always perfect. 

If you go in as a regular customer you get a huge massive portion so much you can barely finish it. 

If you do Meal Pal you get portion leaving you hungry for a second lunch! so unless you're on a diet, they are skimping on the food. Sad.

Additionally the ladies that give out the food are not happy, never smile don't really great you. Very poor customer service.
author: Elizabeth J.

description: Stepped out the Mercedes, walked in for what we thought would be a great first meal of the day but were greeted with disappointment. Nothing else to say except came here during business hours and we were told they are CLOSED! Long story short, it definitely wasn't a picnic.
author: Natasha S.

description: I love that they have a changing meal. The food tastes very homemade and the meat is very tender. The options are very healthy and the staff is friendly.
author: Lucy T.

description:
Charming place overall. A lovely ambiance and I loved the yogurt and granola dish sweetened with homemade apple butter. This place is full of cuteness. 

My only minor complaint so far is that the tea service is about normal for SF/America, which is to say, not that great. Nice selection of fancy-looking tea (Lavender Earl Grey!), but the little spoons at the tea service station are too short for the tall mugs, and there's no dish provided to deposit the used tea bag, for those of us that don't want tea to steep forever. An option for a pot of tea would be lovely for communal tea. Like I said, this is all minor and par for the course for American tea service, but given how cute this place, I think some sort of dainty, well-thought tea service might be a nice addition, perhaps?

Bathrooms: Only one single-occupancy unisex restroom, but spacious, clean, and functional.
author: Jimmy H.

description:
I've been here twice so far (disclaimer: for lunch, not brunch). I enjoy the aesthetic, and there's always table space to sit down (I work in the area and have had two lunch meetings here).

Picnic on Third does combination plates- pork, chicken, and vegetables, in addition to offering items a la carte. I went for the veggie option. The service was quick and efficient, as others have mentioned.

One hiccup: I paid for a komboucha and was told they ran out by a staff member. I decided to wait it out while they refilled it, but was then told the pipe was frozen by another staff person. I was offered a coffee in exchange, which is definitely not the cost of a komboucha.

No, it's not a $20 difference, but the cost of the overall experience doesn't leave me wanting more. But- if you find yourself in looking for a business lunch, this could be the right situation.
author: Nicholas G.

description: First time here! I was on my way to work, and decided to stop by for breakfast. I had "just a damn breakfast". It came with eggs, chicken sausage, and potatoes. The food was great, and I will be coming back here again!
author: William C.

description: The braised beef plate was excellent! So was the agua fresca and cold brew coffee. Everything tasted so fresh and delicious. I can't wait to go, again.
author: R S.

description:
3.5 stars. 

I like this concept of this place. I really want to like the actual place. But after a few times I find myself having a bit of a mixed reaction. 

First, let's describe this place a little. They serve a menu from one cuisine daily, so you something a little different every day. They have a few proteins to choose from, and there's always a vegetarian option. There are also special drinks, desserts, or something to snack on that you can buy. The restaurant is small, and you order first before finding a seat. 

Everything they have sounds good on paper, especially if you are diverse tastes. It will always be interesting. 

My main gripes? Both times I went, there was a little something off with my dish. I usually get one of the main compositions (meat or vegetarian), and I remember a little bitter taste or a little weird flavour in the dish. Not sure if I munched on a bit of a spice pod or a burnt bit - but it stuck, and sorta made the dish much less perfect than it would have been. 

Plus, the dishes are a bit pricey! I realize this is in the city, but I don't work for a fancy start up and so dishing $14 for a normal plate of food seems a bit much. There are way better deals in this part of town. 

However, the "one cuisine a day" concept kept me coming back. Guess I'm still intrigued by surprises!
author: Alice C.

description: I had an egg sandwich 2 weeks ago to go, the English muffin was either old, moldy, or something else bc it tasted like a bums a**hole. Quality control kids!
author: Penguin P.

description:
Picnic on Third is one of my favorite places to think in the morning. Their mornings are usually not too busy and their loose leaf tea hits the spot in the morning. Aesthetically minimalist and nice open wooden counters allow people to digest without clutter.

They're menu is ever-changing and I personally think that people would have polar opinions as their dishes normally have strong flavor profiles. This taste makes them unique, but also can be a bit too strong at times. I've tried a few dishes from time to time and their meats and vegetables tend to be either starkly salty or have strong bites of acidity.
author: Dion L.

description: The quality of the food is fine but considering the price their plates generally leave something to be desired.
author: David K.

description:
TLDR - Low-key, casual place with delicious, healthy compositions and reasonable prices

Came here for Sunday brunch and really enjoyed the food, especially given prices for all the dishes were $15 or less, which is hard to come by for brunch in SF. But sadly, they're no longer offering weekend brunch! I don't work around the area so unfortunately probably won't get a chance to return anytime soon.

I really liked the vibe of the place. Small, quaint, lots of light, casual, laid-back atmosphere. The menu isn't very big, which makes ordering easy, and the food is pretty simple but still delicious. And pretty healthy, well-balanced options overall.

* OVERNIGHT CHILE BRAISED PORK ($13) - 4/5
[poached eggs, cheddar grits, braised collards]
I'm usually not a fan of Southern-influenced dishes like grits and collard greens, but I actually really enjoyed this. The pork was tender and flavorful; the eggs were nicely soft-boiled with a runny yolk; the grits were creamy and buttery, but not at all heavy; and the greens were tender and not overly sour. The chile salt on the eggs was a nice touch too.

* CORNED BEEF HASH ($12.50) - 3.5/5
[fried eggs, fingerlings, brussels, horseradish]
So they actually ran out of corned beef when we came and said they would substitute with a pork instead. Little did we know that pork actually just meant some simple bacon, not pulled pork like I was expecting. Had I known that, I would've asked them to use the chile braised pork instead. I think without the corned beef, this dish was pretty lackluster. The only saving grace was the brussels sprouts, which were delicately crispy and buttery.

* STEEL CUT OATMEAL ($5)
Served with some sort of sweet jam and nut butter. I'm not really an oatmeal person but I did like the jam and nut butter.

* HOUSE YOGURT & GRANOLA ($5)
I wasn't expecting much from yogurt and granola, but the yogurt was surprisingly good. Thick and not too tangy. Good granola too.
author: Jessie L.

description:
A cozy, casual neighborhood venue that offers entrees that are inspired by home cooking and are rotated every day.

I've visited at least three times over the years, and from personal observation, the best time to come here is probably during lunch. Although it gets quite busy here at this time, everything is also being pumped out reasonably freshly. If you get here earlier in the day, there might be some limited breakfast offerings. If you get here late in the afternoon, they might have already sold out of a lot of items, or they might be reheating things from earlier in the day. 

Entrees do indeed feel like honest-to-goodness home cooking, although they can be a tad spendy for what you get. In any case, it's a nice place to pop into if you're already in the neighborhood and aren't pressed for time.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Yummm! Nice, clean lunch spot with a good amount of seating! Super cute ambiance and I like how they give you a display of food plated to help you make your choice. Display really doesn't do the food justice though...cuz there is so much variety and flavor packed into each plate, and it was deceiving.

I ordered the chicken plate with a nice salad and sweet potato gratin. The chicken was tender, though there were some dry bits. The salad was super clean..with not too much dressing! And the sweet potato gratin was fricking amazinggggg!!!

One thing I would not recommend is the Vietnamese iced coffee....wayyyy too much milk and cream! I had 1 shot of espresso and I'm pretty sure the rest was cream! Eeks!

Aside from that, it was soo delicious and definitely a nice spot to meet up a friend for lunch or even as a go-to option. Come early though, it gets super packed during the weekdays... I've seen the line go out the door! Will have to come try it for breakfast on of these days!
author: Jennifer S.

description: Love this restaurant and their daily changing menu with one veggie option and two meet options. I've been here for lunch at least ten times and never ever have I had a dish I didn't like. Its a surprise every time what will be on the menu. With tip the lunch ends up being around $16 which i think its a little bit pricey for a lunch but it's definitely worth it. The food feels very fresh, healthy and homemade. It's a great restaurant for vegetarians.
author: Xi-Er D.

description: You straight up will not find a better breakfast in SF than their corned beef hash. It has real chunks of juicy corned beef (not from a can) with perfectly crispy taters, Brussels sprouts, and topped with gorgeously fried eggs. It makes me so happy.
author: Molly S.

description: This place is on point.  Great concept and execution.  Well worth the night out for this cleaver experience on a date or with a large group.
author: Dan A.

description:
Wow! This place had all my dreams come true.

They combined serious culinary capabilities, with good ingredients, and left out the white table cloths and pretentiousness.

Your order at the counter, get a number and they bring the food to you when it is ready. The location is not in the best place, however, it was convenient for us.

We came here for brunch and everything we had was FREAKING AMAZING.

Coffee, pastries, eggs, everything!

They made this amazing gluten free blueberry muffin that was to die for.

The egg dish was perfectly executed from how the veggies were not overcooked to the perfect egg.

We will definitely be back! They exceeded my expectations.
author: Drew P.

description:
Had lunch here with my wife today and it was like a picnic indoors!

We had the lemon chicken, beef moussaka, and curry soup. Everything was delicious, but I especially liked the moussaka as it was flavorful and went well with the brown rice. It was comfort food to me. I couldn't believe I was eating brown rice as it was so soft and tasty!
The side of salad that came with it too was fresh and had the right amount of dressing, oil, and nuts. 

The place has a hipster-rustic theme which was inviting. I noticed there was also a full menu to get your coffee fix as well. The staff was friendly.
author: Josh L.

description:
I came here a little after 11AM on a Tuesday with my sister. The place was empty - literally no customers - and the woman behind the counter just looked at us blankly when we walked in. When I asked for a menu, she said it was on the chalkboard and gestured to the wall behind us. (I should clarify, she wasn't being rude per se but just very lackadaisical and seemed zoned out, which is whatever.) 

They basically had three options: chicken, pork or vegetarian, with sides of asparagus, slaw, or rice (you pick 2 sides). I ordered the pork with asparagus and slaw after another employee told us you could substitute the sides. The pork was cooked well and was super tasty and hot, but there was a ton of fat. The asparagus was limp and room temperature and the slaw was weirdly oily.  My sister went with the vegetarian option which was literally one deviled egg, with like...probably two cups of rice and asparagus. I felt bad that her meal looked so unappetizing.. the deviled egg portion (seriously one egg?!) was a joke, on top of a huge mound of rice with some limp asparagus. Little dinner rolls were included which was nice but the rolls are clearly pre-packaged (similar to Hawaiian rolls, but with salt on top).

The total came to $27 before tip ($14 for the pork, $13 for the vegetarian) 

Because this place is close and other reviewers have glowing reviews, I'll probably give them another shot, but as it stands the combination of extremely mediocre service and somewhat half-assed food, for now it's a 2/5.
author: Sarah L.

description:
Strong emphasis on real, in processed ingredients. Natural motif through restaurant. "Real meals," like pork shoulder, smoked chicken, fresh salads, breakfast sandwiches, lentils.

Additionally: they do NOT want you pay with cash; AND they expect you to Bus your own table - keep that in mind when calculating your tip.
author: Richard M.

description: It was ok, came here on a work lunch I did not have any choice in. The menu rotates and tries hard to be healthy but comes off kinda blah and depressing feeling. Their rice was very good, fluffy and enjoyable and kinda saved the meal for me. The chicken was meh and the salad was not great. I would not come back, but at least the quality of the ingredients were good even though the prep left a lot to be desired.
author: Baby J.

description:
This cute spot has redeemed SF brunches in my eyes. 

I love it to pieces. I wish there was a 6th star to give. 

My friend and I ordered the bacon (side dish), paleo muffin (yam, almond flour, and pecans), but the entrees were the showstoppers at brunch! They rotate the menus pretty often but if you can catch their corn cake jalapeno pancakes ORDER them! They were so savory, light, and fluffy. I loved the curled pieces of toasted (bacon?) on top and the cheddar cheese baked inside. 

The polenta, slow braised pork dish was also PHENOMENAL. I could lick that plate clean. 

Service was speedy, quick, and the ambiance is really casual, cute, and friendly. It doesn't get too packed and it is the most underrated place in the city. 

Great prices too. $12-15 per entree, $5 per side. So good.
author: Cindy W.

description:
I am still digesting my lunch from this place, so I will give you the nuts and bolts in list form:

Food:  The food was not good, it was great.  Given the comparable options nearby, this place clearly stands out.  This was my first visit, and we came at lunch to order the "Chicken Composition"; that consisted of BBQ Pulled Chicken, Late Summer Heirloom Tomato & Cucumber Salad, Roasted Sweet Potato with Brown Butter and a side of house-made pickles.  

Service:  When we arrived at 12:15p or so, the line was out the door, but moved quickly.  Once we reached the counter to order, you could see why the line moved quickly - very efficient staff.

Experience:  Although the line was a couple dozen deep, we were able to get a table to chow down.  The portions were generous and did not leave me wanting a "lil' bit mo".  

I strongly recommend this place if you have the time to sit down and enjoy a well prepared fast-casual meal at a decent price.
author: Kendall B.

description:
It's often not top of mind for brunch but Picnic on Third is an overlooked spot for a low key weekend brunch. 

On weekday, it feeds a SoMa workers with a daily rotating menu than span cuisines from around the world. It started opening for weekend brunch this year and there are some tasty items on the menu. Begin by sharing a couple of their baked goods like the apple walnut bread for something sweet. For breakfast mains, I really enjoyed the two potato hash. It's surprisingly light and delicate for a traditionally heavy breakfast dish. A mix of regular and sweet potatoes is fried with crispy lardons, Brussels sprouts, and topped off with a fried egg. A delightfully unctuous herb aioli brings it all together -  a nice balance of texture and sweet and savory flavors. 

Washed down with mimosas, we enjoyed our relaxing weekend brunch. It wasn't crowded when we were here and found a table right away. I've heard that they now do bottomless mimosas which makes it even more a reason to return to this hidden gem for weekend boozy brunch.
author: Jon L.

description:
This review is for the coffee, since I have not yet had the pleasure of eating here. 5 stars for the most delicious latte I've had in a long time! 

I was in the mood for something cold, so I ordered the Iced Vietnamese Latte. Thankfully, this drink is not as sweet as Vietnamese lattes at most cafes, so drinking the entire thing is both possible and enjoyable :) Extra points for the egg yolk available for mix in. I had never tried this before, and the yolk added a heavenly layer of  creaminess to the drink. A must try!

The place itself is cute and cozy, and located just a few blocks from my office in SoMa. I'll definitely be back for lunch sometime soon.
author: Yasmin S.

description:
What a cute place! And for a restaurant in SoMa, it's surprisingly NOT closed on Sundays. My boyfriend and I came here to meet up with some friends. We arrived and seated ourselves. It was apparent that we needed to order at the front counter whether we wanted food and/or beverages. They were in no rush to see us leave, despite the fact that we were waiting for 30 minutes before our friends came.

Everything on the menu sounded so tasty. I decided on the Corned Beef Hash because it contained fried eggs, fingerlings, Brussel sprouts, and horseradish. How does that NOT sound amazing?! Our food came in a timely manner, and it was phenomenal. The potatoes were a little dry, but I like the mix of textures and flavors. Would highly recommend this dish, though I believe the menu changes frequently.

I like the vibe of this place, and the name says it all. It does feel like a picnic with friends, or it could be a picnic with strangers if you're seated at the larger communal table. It's a spacious restaurant with friendly service. It's a very "take care of yourself" type of place, contributing to the casual and laid-back atmosphere. I can imagine that lunch gets busy during the week, but it was pretty empty when we went on the weekend. I'd love to come back to try some of their other menu items!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Found this cute neighborhood breakfast/brunch spot through GILT city!

It's small and quaint inside and could be easy to pass by if you're not paying close attention.

Food is delicious, portions are a bit minimal but it's nice so you don't leave overly stuffed and the food is quality.

The menu looks as if it changes daily but I'll upload the pictures of what we got: braised pork and farmer scramble.

The yogurt granola side is DELICIOUS - get that and share it!
author: Anastacia W.

description: What? No more Espresso! I get that Baristas and Espresso machines are a finicky lot, but to toss them both out? Too rash I say. A cup of regular joe is just too harsh to start the day!
author: Stephen I.

description:
Based on the picnic concept espoused here, there's probably a right time to come to this place and alternatively a not-so-right time. Given their 7AM-7PM business hours, I'm guessing 6PM is not the best time to try the menu. It's not that anything is cooked improperly, but most of the food appears to be made earlier in the day and stored in containers (photo: http://bit.ly/1POnHlq). I wasn't aware of the concept behind this SoMa spot until I walked in and asked about the menu. It's a nice-looking space, a bit country kitchenish with an urban vibe. I decided to try the $8 Braised Beef Short Ribs but was told they don't heat up anything.

Uh OK, I guess I'll grab a plate and pour it on there myself. It was a generous portion for sure, with about seven thick slices of beef with gravy (photo: http://bit.ly/1P2p56F). It was high quality and pretty tasty, but oh how I wish it could have been warmed up. I also went for a couple of sides, the $4 Roasted Broccoli and the $4 Grilled Eggplant with Lemon & Oregano. Once again, they were good portions for the price, but eating them cold just wasn't doing it for me. I ended up packing most of it and bringing it home to nuke on my own. Perhaps I should have come with the mindset that this was a takeout spot to avoid a dining disappointment.

FOOD - 3 stars...obviously well made but alas, stored in a container
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...comforting sport to go with the comfort food
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...gee, don't let the door hit ya on the way out
TOTAL - 3 stars...guess I should have brought my own picnic basket
author: Ed U.

description:
This wonderful Mission-esque Marina-esque location feels a bit out of place, but based on the skyrocketing rent in San Francisco, I suspect they were happy to open the doors anywhere they could. 

I absolutely love (when it's effective and execution is right) the down home, laid back, charming crunchy granola concept. This place, for me at least, is crunchy in a good way.

I've never ordered poached eggs. Not once. I've seen them on Food Network, I've heard great things about what I am missing and on this day, it happened. I saw "slow cooked pork" on the menu and quickly ordered it. As I sat at the table, staring out the window at the world passing by, I saw the menu posted on the front window. From the inside out, I could see the item I ordered and poached eggs were coming my way in a matter of moments. My immediate thought was, it's not too late. I can run back to the lovely gal at the counter and tell her that I'm scared of runny yolks. I could run so fast there and back that she's focus more so on my energy than my request. I realized shortly thereafter that this was the day. The day to try what everyone has been so fascinated with. 

The dish was flavorful, the pork was tender, the soft polenta was delicious and I sliced through the poached eggs, one at a time, and mixed the pork, sauce, polenta and yolks together. Pretty darn good. Pretty darn good, but runny yolks, as I anticipated all these years, just isn't my thing. 

I pulled up the website when I got home to learn more about this wonderful restaurant and the ever changing menu, created by different chefs each night, seems intriguing. I will be back this Sunday for more. In fact, I do a sports podcast a few blocks from here every Sunday and I told my crew that we should meet here before the show to grub and prepare for the show. I wanted to try the coffee on my first visit, but I literally had 2 large Philz shortly before I arrived so I will checkout the caffeine this weekend for sure.
author: Hector G.

description:
You may scoff at the prices, but in an area where all you can get are mostly sandwiches, salads, and wraps, a nicely plated warm meal is extremely welcome.

Here's how it works: You peek at the menu outside to see if there's something tasty to your liking. 99% of the time, there's two meat and one vegetarian option, although what you get is a mix and match of several dishes that mix to create a 'composition.'

Pros: Their slow cooked meats are usually pretty amazin'... that kind of fall-off-the-bone goodness. They're usually accompanied with some roasted veggies and a complimentary house-made sauce that they offer at checkout.

Cons: The lines usually run out of the door. Price can put off those who think a $15+ lunch is ridiculous.

All in all, convenience and quality delivered in a streamlined kind of  way -- for those of us who don't have food catered in the office everyday, this is an obvious 2nd best option (but in no way is that a bad thing).
author: Anthony N.

description: Just had lunch for the first time here. Food is really good but the portions are incredible small. I paid $15 for a pork stew that I need a second one of if I plan to be full. Again - delicious food but slightly larger portions would be better to sustain until dinner. Also the house rmusic is ok but does not really present for relaxing atmosphere while trying to relax.
author: Wes B.

description: I went to picnic on third for MealPal lunch today. It is chicken with a side and I picked the roasted veggies. Both are super delicious. I am trying to eat healthy and the combination is just perfect (minimal calories). Chicken is juicy chicken breast and roasted veggies has a hint of curry but not heavy sauces. Definitely will come back again.
author: Suki C.

description: Nice design. Limited brunch menu. Cute way to display your croissant (with a cazuelita, which is more associated to Spanish tapas or creme brulee). Located at a corner of SoMa that seems to be having always some sort of construction, its clean design and the signs outside displaying the menu will caught your attention. Is a cute place for breakfast but not convincing enough for something else. Pleasant atmosphere.
author: Carmen V.

description:
TL;DR - Ok food, high prices, weird service. 

Ok, I'm all about paying more for food if the quality is there. But.... its really not.

The idea is kinda cool, you know, a changing daily menu. However, the quality is pretty similar to Lemonade (at like 2-3x the price)

There is no table bussing or anything. You get your food in a cafeteria style kind of line. One plate lunch was over $17 (w/ tip) Wtf? The portions were not what I would expect for that price tag. The mac salad was kinda water-y. The slaw was bland. Only the pork was kind of flavorful (but overly salty). 

Yes, I'm pulled in by the cute concept, but I can't be ok with paying that price for just an ok lunch. 

Fun to check out once, definitely won't be back.
author: Crystal Z.

description: Rude barista and closes before the stated closing time of 5pm. They stop serving food apparently by 2:30. Go somewhere else if you want a drink or food for happy hour. Here's what happened: Came in at 4:25pm- sign in the door said closes at 5pm. I was just looking for a quick glass of wine (happy hour would be nice) while I waited for a friend. The woman who served me seemed irritated I was there and before I even ordered, she promptly informed me they were only serving "water, iced tea and maybe tea. Food closed at 2:30.". I asked "do you have wine?" The barista seemed annoyed at this and needed to check if wine was still available... I should have gone somewhere else at that point. $8 for a glass of rosé and $7 for a can of beer. No thanks!!
author: Erin M.

description:
I had the pleasure of coming here on a Sunday afternoon for lunch. I chose to eat the two-hash which has potato totters with a lightly fried egg, brussel sprouts, green onion and bacon bits. Even though it was a light lunch, it was super delicious it felt pretty healthy compared to most other lunches I've had in the city. Everything was lightly fried or baked

I really liked how everything blended together very well in the dish, they put a lot of thought of which ingredients to put, how much to put and even plated it fairly well. I really enjoyed this meal because it tasted so good together and I'll definitely be back again.

My friend got the pancakes and they were really filling but delicious. They had this cranberry-maple syrup sauce with real cranberries and pancakes that were made fresh with a unique batter that resulted in a nice thick pancake. You could feel the coarseness of the pancake as you eat it, like it breaks down into chunks, it's hard to explain but it makes it feel like you're eating authentic pancakes.
author: Christopher L.

description: Nice people who take your order, fresh quality food, what more can one want.  Nicely decorated like some barnyard farmer's place, beautiful spice rack wall, wooden table.  Had the grits and eggs and brussel sprouts.   Steelcut oatmeal with strawberry butter?  My favorite is the fresh fruit bowl. Portions will leave you full and satisfied.  Very casual,  order, pay, take a number, place on your table and food arrives shortly.  Unfortunately,  brunch on Saturdays and sundays between 10 to 2 pm,  is quite limited time.  Plenty of parking and free parking on sundays.
author: Helen L.

description:
I feel like I'm one bad meal away from not coming to this place. Today they served lemon chicken, and not only was the portion small (1 piece of chicken + 1 piece of skin), but almost inedible because it was hard, dry, and greasy. 

This place has a good concept-- home cooked dishes with daily rotation-- but like the food of an inexperienced home cook, the dishes are hit or miss, and most of the time, miss.
author: Apple M.

description:
Wow! Was not expecting this little spot on third to have such delicious and high quality food but it was fantastic!

The staff was warm and friendly and even though the place was pretty packed, our food was brought out quickly. The actually food was amazing. I got the smoked salmon and eggs and it came with a good portion of smoked salmon and perfectly scrambled eggs.

The place is small and quaint but perfect for a casual Saturday brunch. Oh, didn't have them but there's bottomless mimosas for $14!

Definitely my new go-to brunch spot!
author: Loryn F.

description:
This place is super cute! It's kind of tucked away but once you find it, you'll be glad you did.

They don't have much choices for anything, but my friends and I shared a charcuterie and cheese platter and I was pleased. I used a gilt city coupon so it was totally worth it... although I think I'll come back even without a coupon :)
author: Angela L.

description:
I love the concept. Home-cooked food, fusion, chef creations. It's an incredibly popular lunch place in SOMA, and most everyone I know loves this place. 

Except me. 

I've been here about four times so far, and the menu's always changing. But I've never been blown away by the food--in fact, I've always been slightly disappointed in my order. One time, it was a curry; another time, it was some type of poultry (which was overcooked). Today, I opted for the pastrami creation, which came with green beans sauteed with slice almonds and a latke. The pastrami wasn't great. The green beans were...uninspiring would be the best word, I guess, as much as food can be inspiring or not. There were several I ate that made me suspect these were canned, but I highly doubt they are. The latkes were overfried and hard as a rock on the outside. 

$15 and I left most of my food on the plate. I don't really know what to say about this place... I just wish the food tasted better.
author: Evelyn C.

description:
During lunch time, Picnic is like a simplified version of Lemonade. There are a only a couple of combinations possible and for that reason, I prefer Lemonade. My lunch rating for Picnic would be 3 stars.

Brunch is a whole other story. My friend and I were looking for a spot near both of us and she suggested Picnic. I was a little hesitant due to my prior lunch experience but Picnic's brunch truly blew it out of the water. This is a hidden gem that doesn't require you to get up before the crack of dawn and wait for hours in line to get served.

The brunch menu is small but each item is well thought out and executed. I ordered the cornmeal cheddar pancakes, which sounded interesting and tasted amazing. It was a feast for the eyes and the belly. The pancake batter was light and fluffy. The prosciutto and green onions added the right savory flavors to balance the dish. It was definitely an unique dish I haven't seen elsewhere. For $12, it was an excellent bargain and the portion size was deceivingly large. I would not hesitate to go back to Picnic for brunch.
author: Yi Z.

description: $20.20 for a muffin and lunch. My lunch was cold and the chicken was very dry. The muffin was delicious, but not $5 delicious. If you're made of money this is the place for you. If you like warm food, go elsewhere.
author: Matt H.

description:
I'm glad I got a Gilt deal that helped me discover this cute little spot! It was $25 for 2 coffees/juices, 2 starters, and 2 entrees (which would've cost about $35).

No wait around 10:30am on the Sunday after Thanksgiving. You order at the counter and seat yourself. Our food came out very quickly. The servers were really chill and nice. 

* Homemade chai ($4.50) - 2.5 stars
Quite watery, a bit lacking in flavor.

* Persimmon spice bread ($2.50) - 3.5 stars
Very nice, you can definitely taste the cinnamon-y spice. Dense texture, a tad on the dry side, and the nuts go really well. 

* Brown sugar bacon ($5) - 4 stars
Very delicious. Thick pieces, nice balance of the sweet and the savory.

* Two-potato hash (bacon lardons, brussels sprouts, herb aioli & fried eggs. $12.50) - 4 stars
My boyfriend wasn't a fan, but this was nice and light, just what I was looking for. The potatoes were a tad dry, but they had good flavor. 

* Overnight chile pork & soft polenta (collard greens, sous vide poached eggs. $13) - 4 stars
A bit heavy for me. I didn't like the collard greens, but I never like collard greens. It added a sour flavor. My boyfriend really liked this, and the eggs were just perfect. Polenta was fantastic.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
I really, really, really wanted to like this place but the food just wasn't good.

I was excited to try this place after reading the reviews and seeing that it was inspired by Pok Pok. I was even more excited after I walked in and smelled the wonderful smells and talked to the staff, who were all energetic and competent.

There's a couple of issues with the food:

1) Lukewarm. The food wasn't hot, it wasn't even warm. There is only so much ability for food that isn't hot to be tasty.

2) Flavor. I got the chicken, my husband got the pork. We've had tons of fish sauce / larb dishes. This ranked in the bottom 20%. The chicken wings didn't have enough meet and there wasn't enough sauce. 

3) Under salted.

4) Chai was just like foam. It barely tasted of a tea.

This place has all the makings of something wonderful. Maybe they were having an off meal. But we were underwhelmed and wish that we had gone elsewhere for lunch.
author: Lilly D.

description:
Wowww! My co-workers told me about this place, first I was skeptical because I don't usually like Fusion dishes, but I became the biggest fan of Picnic!! 

Everything I've tried here really impressed me, they change menu everyday, 3 options everyday and one is vegetarian. I have yet to find a restaurant like this and they really does every dish very well, and really creative, you can't find dishes like that anywhere in one small restaurant. Not only the food taste good, it is usually relatively healthy, and the presentation is great, you can tell they really put alot of effort and heart to make those dishes.

The drinks are also very good, they change it up everyday too, that's why I have been here almost 3-4 days a week and haven't been tired of it.

The serving size though, is on the small side for the price ( about $15 for a lunch plate ), but I don't really mind because the food are phenomenal. 

The people work here are very friendly and work fast as well, on a busy weekday lunch the line could get long but usually move very fast.

I subscribed to their newsletter to see what they have for the week! lol big fan here!
author: Kassi O.

description:
Love this place. 

They make the "plat du jour" concept of a delicious home cooked tasting entree and side set work. Maybe you're not sure what you're going to get but you're pretty sure it's going to be good. 

There are enough options that you're not boxed into a today's special that is your worst nightmare but few enough that you don't really have to make any real ordering decisions. 

Style is "home-cooked" and mixed ethnicity. I've had Asian style eggplant and slow cooked chicken; cous cous and Thai green curry with beef. So don't expect anything specific!

Line is usually out the door but moves quickly. 

Only real drawback? It's kind of expensive. Lunch runs about $15 with no beverage.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Good food, menus rotating everyday, 3 different choices most of the time. 

Meat and vegetarian options, and multiple sides to swap.

I would say that the price is a bit high, but I am not sure of their costs so hard to tell.

Food is of quality though, and I love that they have kimchi or other to-go options to complement the meal or take home.
author: Bruno P.

description: Loving this place! I've only had breakfast here - specifically only the breakfast sandwich (with bacon). At $5 for something this delicious, it's too a good of a deal for me to try other things on the menu. However, what I've seen on other plates looks equally as attractive. Coffee is  as well.
author: Matt T.

description: Cool concept, great decor. I'd need to go a few times to see if the flavor is better in other dishes but while everything I had was cooked well, it lacked flavor. What kind of mustard chicken doesn't taste like mustard? Loved their paleo dessert options. I had the carrot muffin and it was bomb for a gluten free desert!
author: Taylor F.

description:
I was in the city for another convention and looking for a quick breakfast and a tasty adult beverage to start the day off well. Well... I happened upon this little gem of a coffee shop that just happened to serve awesome breakfast sandwiches AND had a nice assortment of local microbrews! So my morning was off to a nice start. 
   I asked and was quickly answered by the attentive staff what the draft beer selection was and got a great recommendation for the breakfast sandwich. I went with a light field (or something like that) IPA and a breakfast sandwich. The IPA was delicious as one could imagine and the breakfast sandwich hit the spot like a cannon!
   The sandwich was a egg/cheese blend cooked perfectly but shaped a bit too perfectly  (looked like a McDonald's egg). It was topped with yummy bacon and served between two halves of an English muffin, YUM! Just the right sized bite to file my big day in the city.
   If I lived in the city this could surely be a favorite spot for me, give them a try!
author: Mark F.

description:
High quality, rotating food menu served in a cafeteria-like setting. Weird? Nah, not really. Think of your Chipotles or tech company cafes, but, well, nicer.

The day I went, they were serving up a slightly Thai-themed menu, where I ordered a lemongrass pork shoulder for my main, and bok choy and papaya salad for my sides. Great flavors all around, but the pork was far too salty for my tastes, and there was not a grain of rice to be had, which was unfortunate, to say the least.

And while the prices are definitely on the higher side, I can see myself possibly coming back if I were in the area, just to check out a different menu. Given that I work all the way in FiDi, it's unlikely to happen anytime soon though!

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - A midsize venue, with pretty spacious/open seating. That said, the tables are a bit on the smaller / more narrow side, so wheelchairs may have trouble scooting themselves between the legs of the tables. **Edit** The owner of Picnic messaged me and pointed out that they actually have reserved wheelchair tables, which I'm pretty sure I made the mistake of NOT sitting at. So, bear in mind that while the two tops may be too narrow, there should be otherwise accessible tables.

Bathroom - Didn't try them, so no comment.
author: Johnny W.

description:
I really wanted to like this place! The lil smiling squid on the cup is so cute! The decor is so chic and rustic without looking dingy. The concept is so simple. I rooted for you POT, I really did. So much so that during heated office debates about you, I defended your honor, despite never crossing your threshold.

Sadly, today that changed and I wonder if I should have just left it an idea. As I mentioned, the votes were not in on lunch, so I thought I'd give the breakfast a try. Had an almond milk latte, and while delicious and beautiful, it was pretty lukewarm. As for the sandwich (option for bacon: yes please!), as you can see from my picture it's 90% egg, and the other 10% bread/ bacon. Some people might like that extra egg but this thing was a beast, and i had to give up halfway through. I wondered: is the vegetarian version just one big egg puck? Unfortunately for me my tummy ached for the rest of the day: grumble grumble.

Service was quick and friendly. They have cute lil snacks for sale as well. Sorry Picnic, it's not a match for me. I'll still root for you from the sidelines.
author: Alyssa J.

description: Granola was good and side of scrambled eggs was good. Good prices. Cute place. Service is as good. Will definitely be back.
author: Olivia L.

description:
I had heard great things about this place so my friend and I decided to try it out for lunch one day. 

I ordered the sampler plate with a little bit of everything, LOVE that they have this option so i could try a little bit of everything. 

The food was tasty (mac and cheese, kale salad, green beans) but everything was mushy and the kale salad had a little too much dressing. Not totally sure if I'll be back.
author: Ilana B.

description:
Having recently returned home to SF, I noticed this place on the new businesses list no more than a few blocks away from home. With good reviews and an interesting menu I decided to stop by here for lunch today.

The interior is nice and new, with lots of seating and a full coffee bar. The service here was especially friendly and helpful with one member immediately coming up to me to explain the menu and tell me about the business as soon as I walked in the door.

The menu here seems to change ever day with the two owners also being the chefs. Each day they choose a different theme (like chinese, southern, indian, etc.) Your options consist of three plates, two of which are meat and one is vegetarian, but you have the option to get any of the items ala carte. There are also pastries from a couple of different bakeries around town.

Today's theme was indian and I tried the Masala Roasted Chicken, the Lamb Curry and the Ginger Cauliflower, all ala carte. Both the chicken and the lamb were both pretty good. The cauliflower was not so great. 

An issue that comes to mind while ordering and eating is that all of the dishes are simply sitting out in bowls and served from there. Perhaps this is because the business is new, but everything would be very much improved if they were kept under warming lights or some other way to keep it all heated up.

Overall, I liked Picnic on Third a lot and I look forward to returning here to try foods from the different themes that the chefs come up with. I also like their location and the feel of their shop. I'd definitely say that "I'm a fan."
author: Mark O.

description: I searched for Paleo on yelp.  This was a little out-of-the-way, but the menu seems interesting. I'm glad I went a few block out of my way.   Great food, healthy, and good service. I have the pork shoulder and grilled cabbage. Both were excellent
author: Michael P.

description: Little pricey, but what isn't in San Francisco? This place is good for brunch and has some yummy dishes! We got the corned beef hash and (I forgot the name) some kind of pulled pork with poached eggs on top. Also got the Vietnamese iced coffee that had the egg yolk mixed into it! I think its an option to add the egg, but do it! It makes the coffee so frothy and creamy.
author: Larissa L.

description:
FAST and friendly service! healthy food! easy to get a table! i'm coming back again 2 days in a row. this is a huge win in my book. 

Yes you will pay a little extra (~$13), but you're treating your body right. That's worth it. This is located on the same block as garaje, right near the freeway underpass. They have beer and wine if that suits your fancy.

The menu changes every day so be sure to check the website for what's upcoming. Today I ate the most tender chicken, smashed potatoes, and radicchio.
author: Kailey O.

description:
Very cute concept (and website design, for that matter), but unfortunately, the picnic we picked up was incredibly salty, the meat was dry, and in general just devoid of flavor. The boy brought their specials of the day to my office for an afternoon lunch, and while it was a wonderful gesture, we were both left very, very thirsty. We shared:
~GROUND PORK w/WHEAT NOODLES
~SEARED CHICKEN w/SAUTEED WATER SPINACH

I agree with the comment from Alice S. - this food reminds me of home-cooking in a less-than-positive way.
author: Claire S.

description:
Picnic on Third is the way lunch ought to be: simple, delicious, nourishing and easy. You'll stand in line for a bit but don't worry because it moves fast. And because they make only a couple of mains and a few sides each day (all of which are ready when you arrive) you'll be eating your lunch in no time.

Every day the menu is inspired by a theme (hot summer nights) or a different place in the world (Hokkaido, Japan). On the day I came to Picnic, I had Harissa roasted beef, warm yellow potatoes and cucumber tomato and red onion salad with preserved lemon. It was one of the best lunches I've had in SoMa in quite a while.

I can't wait to return!

Notes:
- Cookies are good
- They have freshly squeezed grapefruit juice
- You can mix and match the mains and sides
author: Miriam W.

description: Picnic on Third is my new favorite spot! It's my first time visiting San Francisco. I always like to try new places but when I ate here yesterday, I knew I had to come back! There is no need to try a new place when you've found one like this where the food is amazing, homemade, and where the menu options change daily! The staff is friendly and genuine, which makes the whole experience very pleasant. Thank you for this experience, I hope to come back to SF on a trip again soon and come enjoy more of Picnic on Third!
author: Tatyana M.

description:
The brunch menu is very limited and the combinations don't work if you're vegetarian, as we are. I love Brussel sprouts, but with the bitterness of them with egg and potatoes, the combo didn't work.

The pancakes with cheddar cheese and scallions didn't work either.

Again, they may work better with the meat additions, but be warned if you are a vegetarian, the combos just don't work.

Everyone there is super nice and the space is ok, nothing special, but with the location and us not being wowed, we won't return.
author: Ernest M.

description: Awesome concept and fantastic, imaginative staple fare! Be prepared for a line when you visit Picnic at noontime, but know it moves fast! Order tasty twists on down-home favorites a la carte or as a full plate lunch. Grab a seat and tuck in, or get yours to go and head to South Park. Always a winner.
author: Laura M.

description:
Solid lunch option if you are in the SOMA area. Today a group of four of us came for brunch and we all ordered 4 different things which was coincidentally how many different brekkie entrees they had. 

Sides: Yogurt with granola and side of fruit-fruit was really sweet, seasonal, good portions. Granola tasted very high quality-house made

Drinks: Grapefruit juice-fresh squeezed; iced latte-very good

Entrees: The hubs had the potato scramble hash with bacon, I had the pulled pork and polenta. Both were a little heavy handed on the salt if it was just a little less salty it would have been really good.

The ambience is nice, a little neighborhood cafe, not a lot of room for large groups though with the exception of one table that could squeeze in about 8, all the other tables are for 2-4 max.
author: Betty C.

description:
ALL THE NOMS. No. Seriously. All of them. 

Every single time I walk in here, which is on average one to two times a week for lunch, I think to myself "this is the most underrated place in the area -- if not the entire city." 

The food is hands down phenomenal. Every damn thing I've had here. Amazingly delicious. And for the SAME price as my standard do-it-yourself salad at Whole Foods. For the portion and the flavor, they could charge twice as much. Hell, I'd pay twice as much.

In the meantime, I'll give it 5 stars and still call it the most underrated restaurant in the city.
author: Meredith O.

description:
tl;dr High-quality ingredients prepared in a not-that-interesting way.

The line at HRD was too long, so decided to give this a try. I got the $13 vegetarian combination. Quantity was good, and it was a good mix of ingredients, but some of the texture was too mushy for me. Flavor on the bland side. There were salt shakers on the tables but I didn't see any pepper, and I'm a pepper kind of person. (I could have gotten chimichurri sauce but it's hard to un-do sauce once you've done it if you don't like it.)

They appear to be card-only. They use Square, which I don't like because they sent me my signature through email, which isn't necessarily secure, so I usually try to pay cash with Square vendors. Also, Square's default tips choices are No, 15%, 20%, and 25%, which is high (I'm not going to no-tip) for a place where you order, pay, and pick up your order at the counter and bus your own table. Sure, I could have done the Custom Tip option, but I was already not happy with having to use Square and wanted to end the interaction as quickly as possible.
author: Charles B.

description: Such a great place to eat.  I work in the area and the restaurant is a standout.  Great friendly staff. Menu changes daily, always a hit the food is fantastic. Varied by countries or type of food.  They do know how to cook and great food.
author: M Jake M.

description:
Came in to try the breakfast sandwich one morning and I'm now a regular morning customer here!

Great little cafe for doing work. South Park is around the corner but this place opens early and has free wifi. Usually there's just a little foot traffic coming in and out to get coffee but no one ever sits down.

They have an UNBELIEVABLE breakfast sandwich (get it with bacon) for $5 and they serve contraband coffee (another one of my favorite cafes). The staff is always extra chipper in the morning, the place is clean and the music is great.
author: Sarah F.

description:
The food was pretty good. I just got a lunch to go (sausage). Definitely prepared after I ordered it and didn't taste like it had been sitting under a sun lamp. 

I would probably eat here again, although probably not every day. 

It does have a nice atmosphere and it is good for lunch. Definitely quieter in the late afternoon, say 3-4pm. Good for getting stuff done.
author: Elliot L.

description:
I wish I could fit Picnic on Third into my kitchen. This is where I want to be on a Sunday morning. Coffee, various parts of pork cooked in different ways, all covered with eggs...is everything I need to prepare me for Monday.

Minus 1 star for location, it should be closer to my house.. Parking is a hit or miss.
author: kim w.

description: Good food but super slow.  The ready to go stuff you get right away, i.e. Muffins, breads, yogurt etc... but the main dishes that need cooking take a long time.
author: Chi Z.

description:
Lovely new restaurant in SoMA! It is a bit on the pricier side (lunch can be around $14+) and the portions are a bit small but the food is delicious and I love that the menu changes everyday! I came here for lunch with a coworker when the menu was Filipino food (chicken and pork belly adobo). I couldn't decide on what to get so I ended up doing half half. So glad that they let you do half half for those people who have a hard time making up their mind! I have no regrets on either. The pork belly and chicken were both tender and cooked in amazing adobo sauce. For my sides, I decided to get rice and eggs (if you chose eggs they give you 2 hard boiled eggs). Both were yummy. I was tempted to get the mango salsa they offered at the end, but everything was a la cart and I'm trying to save for a wedding so I decided to hold back. I just might go crazy one day and pile everything on! 

The place was pretty packed during lunch so it can be hard to find a seat but my coworker and I got lucky and were able to grab the last available table. Someone helps with pouring water and utensils are available at the table. 

Overall, good dining experience and I would come back but it would have to be when I allow myself to splurge on lunch every now and then. Btw - although the portions are small, I only ate half my meal and when I had the other half for lunch the next day, it was even more delicious! Haha...
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Great concept, great food, great coffee! SOMA has really exploded and in its wake a culinary scene has emerged! Picnic on Third is one of the noteworthy. It's a concept that is so obviously great that you wonder why it didn't happen sooner. It is a literal picnic on 3rd Street. The seating is counter, communal, or tables for two and the menu changes daily with three inspired "Chef Compositions" which is a selection of an entree, (options are usually a choice of beef, chicken, seafood, or vegetarian) with choices of sides. There's also the option to order a la carte to mix and match.

The menu follows a different theme each day. I came in on a day the menu was South Korea inspired. Since I usually opt for the veggie I got the Gochujang Roasted Tofu, which came with vermicelli noodles with green onion and bean sprouts, daikon with water spinach, cucumber and carrot salad, and house made kim chi. I've looked at the menus since and saw a Spanish inspired menu as well as a menu inspired by "German Immigrants in 19th century New York." Oh the the brilliance of gourmet cuisine in a quick service setting. The possibilities are endless.
author: Clare B.

description: They forgot to mention their full price lattes come in half sizes if you ask for less ice. Who knew ice added so much space
author: Eva Z.

description:
It's tough to quickly and simply define why I love Picnic so much, other than to say that it's a combination of factors both tangible and intangible that just add up to magic. 

On the tangible side:
- A delightfully creative and diverse menu that changes every day, with 3 entree options that cut across cuisines--often on the same plate
- Superb parfait with housemade granola and unique housemade jams
- Solid breakfast sandwich
- Great coffee--especially the cold brew
- Excellent beer options for later

Intangibles:
- Laidback atmosphere--this despite the flocks of startup folks (myself included) that swarm the place at lunch
- Fantastic staff--within a few visits, they'll know your name, how you take your coffee, and what you'll probably order for lunch. I love these people. 
- Real commitment to re-use--everything they make seems to turn into a kind of pickle you've never encountered before, or a great to-go option

My only caveat is that, due to the rotating menu, it's not a win every day. But tomorrow ... tomorrow will be great. 

Give it a shot, really.
author: John W.

description:
LOVE picnic. I come here several times a week for lunch but never get bored of the food since the menu changes daily. Their food is made with love, and the staff are just genuinely good, nice people. 

Highlights:
1) I still dream about their ox tail. If you're lucky and come in on a day when it's on the menu, DON'T THINK and just freaking get it. And order an extra one to go. It's seriously that good, and such a deal for the price.
2) Leigh's sourdough chocolate chip cookies are crack. If you see them on the cookie display, just get it. They sell out quick.
3) Also, their almond croissants.
4) The vegetarian options are legit. I'm not vegetarian (per above comment re: oxtail dreams), but sometimes will opt for their veg option b/c it looks so yummy. 

Finally, Chefs Natalia and Leigh are wonderful humans. We hosted a fundraiser event here and Natalia & Leigh are seriously the best. This is a great place to do private events. Thank you so much for everything!
author: suzanne l.

description: Great spot for a weekday breakfast when you want to pretend it's actually the weekend and you're at a sumptuous brunch with loved ones. I also find their lunch to be generously portioned, I'd just suggest checking the website in advance to see what the daily specials are as the menu is pretty streamlined.
author: Erin W.

description:
I've come to Picnic on Third for Sunday brunch, lunches, and happy hours.  I always find something delicious and nutritious to eat, and always walk away stuffed!  

Their lunch concepts are so well thought out and I love that the menu changes every day, it seems like they never run out of new ideas!  I look forward to their weekly newsletters so even when I can't make it out for lunch, I can spy on their menu for my own cooking inspiration.

You can tell the owners are passionate about this concept and their food, and it shows in every dish they serve. 5 stars all day, every day
author: Katie R.

description:
Came here for a soft opening and immediately fell in love. High quality delicious food that nails excellence without being pretentious. Meals are served as plates: choose your protein and a few sides. 1 main + 2 sides runs ~$12, well worth it for the quality. There were only 2 main dishes and about 5 sides to choose from when I was there and they say that they rotate them daily, which I really like because it simplifies choosing (great for an indecisive person like me!), is really fast, and you know that you're getting something with fresh ingredients being prepared with lots of TLC. Also means that you can keep going back without having to sacrifice food variety!

They have both takeout and seating options. Friendly laid back vibe and cool decor. I hear they made the tables themselves out of butcher blocks & pipes (neat!)

And the coffee - oh the coffee! - possibly the best latte I've ever had. I think they're using ritual coffee and must have some special high quality milk as it was perfection in both flavor and creamy mouthfeel. I will be back.

Edit: Coffee update - it's actually Contraband Coffee & Halfwit out of Chicago
author: Alissa B.

description:
This place is awesome. I don't give reviews often, but Picnic deserves it.

I work in the area and am always somewhat frustrated by the limited healthy options. Yeah, I could trek to whole foods for a salad or the paleo bar, but I feel like I'm paying for more than its worth sometimes. After stopping by on opening day today, I'm thrilled to say Picnic delivers the goods, and is a welcome addition to the neighborhood. 

A needed departure from the fru-fru bistro fare in South Park, where a small salad costs a fortune, this place features simple but nourishing food. Choose your delicious meat, select your seasonal veggies, and sit down for a tasty meal in a chill environment. 

What more could you ask for?
author: Bryan T.

description:
My husband saw this place near his work and we decided to try it. Boy am I glad we did. Fresh, authentic and fullllll of flavor!!! I had the chicken meatballs over grains, baba ganoush and a date chutney. Sooooo good.
The decor inside is beautiful. The kitchen looks like a large kitchen you would see in someone's home. The staff is very friendly. A must on your list.
author: claire m.

description:
Offering healthy, upscale cuisine in a café setting, Picnic on Third is a welcome addition to South Beach.

With a menu that changes daily, Picnic on Third is a new go-to lunch spot. One day uber-tender chicken, creamy smashed potatoes, and radicchio; another day super-succulent lamb, two-cous salad, and roasted eggplant. What's not to love?

The concept is simple: each day Picnic on Third offers two delicious entrees and three interesting sides. You pick an entree and whichever two sides pique your interest, plunk down $13, and enjoy. Of course, there are the requisite espresso drinks and pour-over coffee for caffeine lovers as wells as beer and wine for the imbibers.

Everything is available for dine-in or take out, but, with the high quality of the food, you really shouldn't put it in a (compostable) box.

The fast, friendly service makes you want to return. Servers are upbeat, with just enough snarkiness to be funny.

Word to the wise:  leave your greenbacks at home--Picnic on Third is credit only. At least for now. Until they see their bill from Square. Ouch.

SOMA dwellers run; do not walk. Picnic on Third delivers tasty, reasonably priced, healthy food in a warm, casual setting.
author: CJ G.

description:
Everything you need from an SF lunch spot -

Healthy portions
Amazing quality and taste
Varied menu
Very quick for either a sit down or to go 
Great ambience 
Booze!
author: Alex S.

description:
This is by far my favorite lunch spot in San Francisco. New menu items every day, super fun and friendly staff, everything tastes incredible (no really, the masterminds behind this place deserve recognition for creating great dishes that are healthy and tasteful)

Also, the price is perfect - especially when you take into account the quality of the ingredients (everything is fresh and nutritional)

Boom! Go check it out for yourself - you'll be glad you did! :)
author: William W.

description: They have several types of premade combinations platters to choose from, which they call chef's compositions. I chose the veg one and it did not disappoint. The vegetables were diverse and were nicely seasoned. Overall, this was a healthy lunch option.
author: James S.

description: Just tried their latte - was good! The service is nice and accommodated some customizations graciously. They have good seating, and have some nice options for lunch.
author: Gul G.

description:
excellent brunch venue. enjoyed the overnight braised pork with poached egg on polenta. and a glass of house red. 

the staff is friendly and thoroughly answered my questions.  

will definitely return on my next trip to the city.
author: Rob T.

description:
ALSO, if you are looking for a totally delicious lunch for your office, they can do that too! Finding reasonably priced, quality lunches that delivers to FiDi for an office of 20 foodies is sometimes a pain, but I'll def be ordering from Picnic again. 

Our staff lunch was a hit with everyone, and they were so impressed with the daily menu change concept. It's really hard to do a variety of types of food very well, but they do it!
author: Adele A.

description:
I could not love this place more!!! Why? Too many reasons to list. I'll try though:
1) The most amazing and friendly staff, for real, super great service 
2) The food is SO good, everything on the menu, delicious 
3) The best vegetarian options in town
4) Damn good beer on draft (perfect chill spot to snag one before heading to a game at AT&T)
5) Seriously good coffee and baristas that know what they are doing 

How do I know all of this? I work next store. Lucky me. I've had every meal there, and honesty will be sad when I'm not located right next to this spot.
author: Gina H.

description: We came in on a Sunday morning for coffee and were presently surprised by the healthy, fresh breakfast items: homemade yogurt and granola, salmon and egg scramble, and fresh seasonal fruit (pomegranate!). The decor is chic, but rustic and the staff is friendly and mellow.
author: Jacqueline S.

description: Love, love, love this place.   We've been 4-5 times this Giants baseball season coming in on BART and usually arrive before they start serving lunch at 11:00. No worries, a great cup of pour over coffee while we wait.  Their food is healthy, fresh, creative and varied. We leave feeling comfortable, and satisfied that we've eaten well.  The concept is different, no set menu but always 3 protein options, and 4 sides.  Today we had lentils, green bean salad with a tapenade dressing, romaine salad with fennel and a delicious tomato and eggplant gratin. They always have an extra which is typically a sauce.  Today was a Salsa verde style sauce with roasted almonds.  Delicious - all of it.  Didn't have them today but their sourdough chocolate chip cookies are to die for!
author: Karen S.

description:
Best lunch ever, best customer service ever. 

Their cold brew with almond milk. Holy amazingness, I have dreams about it. 

Also, the best almond croissant I've ever had (flaky, moist, not overly sweet). 

Menu changes daily, and is guaranteed fresh and inventive, with quality ingredients. The line moves super fast (they're pros) so even at rush hour it's still a quick, healthy, delicious option. I can't get enough of it. Thank you to the whole team for keeping me caffienated, fed, and laughing! :)
author: Lindsey S.

description: This review is only for their coffee and espresso drinks. Came by on a Sun early afternoon and the place was very very quiet. Our drinks were quickly made and we were on our way. My $2.75 cup of coffee was just average. The ambiance of the place was cute, especially the spice wall. Looks like most of the great reviews are for their food, which we did not try. The food menu I briefly looked at had only a few choices and they didn't seem to be very healthy. One thing that bothered me a bit was seeing jugs of juices left sitting out uncovered - not sure if these were going to be discarded or served to customers. Oh and not a big deal but they don't accept ca$h.
author: Yin H.

description:
Great food and ambiance for Soma. It's tucked away behind the freeway and the place is either chef's choice or build your own à la carte meal. I ended up going à la carte until my à la carte became what the chef had recommended (basically all of the veggie options on one plate). The meal was Israeli/Mediterranean themed (I believe they change every day) and I love love loved my Israeli couscous (little pearls of goodness in your mouth!). The kale sale was also really good and I usually do not opt for kale or salad! One thing that was a bit weird was their "baba ganoush". Normally, baba ganoush is a creamy eggplant dip (similar to the consistency of hummus). Theirs, on the other hand, was more like softly boiled eggplant. Still good, but the description threw me off.

I'd definitely come back here again to try some of their other themed meals :).
author: Christina C.

description:
One of my issues with working at an office in SOMA (South Park) is the seemingly lack of lunch options, compared to the FiDi. I got tired of my routine of Chipotle/Freshroll in the Metron and the generally-flavorless Whole Foods SOMA hot bar so decided to try Picnic on Third. I must say - this is a really solid spot. The food is varied as the menu changes everyday so all cuisines seem to be equally represented. The flavors are also very unique and interesting - MUCH better than Whole Foods.

The thing that I like the most about Picnic is that you can order (veggie) sides for $3. So, whether you are very hungry or just a little hungry you can get the appropriate amount of food. I've found their sides to be decently large so two sides for a total of $6 is a good deal in my book. This is actually one place where it pays to be vegetarian/vegan. I'm always irked when restaurants charge the same for veggie/tofu dishes as meat - clearly meat is more expensive!
author: Sarah S.

description:
Probably the best meat loaf I've ever eaten... soooo perfectly moist, and with a burst of flavor! 
The dessert chocolate chip cookie did not dissapoint either. 
BRAVO Leigh and Co!
Can't wait to go back and taste other items on their menu ;-)
author: Kicka W.

description: This is the second time I've hosted a small gathering of friends at Picnic, once was lunch time and another was a happy hour time. Amazing, delicious food; thoughtful menus that make for fun combinations of flavors. The first time there was a bit of a Moroccan theme (a tagine, maybe?). At happy hour your food options are limited to charcuterie-type items, but they also have food from the lunch service packaged to-go for you to take away for dinner. The food they had to go was a few (really reasonably priced) items from an Asian-inspired lunch service that looked really delicious. We opted for that (so good) and the servers were nice enough to warm it up and bring it to us at a table. Great wine choices. Can't wait to come back to try out their brunch some day soon.
author: Michelle L.

description: Fantastic fresh food. Limited menu, super seasonal. Gets packed at lunch. Easy to get things to go, and line moves pretty smoothly. Service is extremely friendly.
author: Amy O.

description: Way overpriced for what it is. I want to love this place and this was my second time trying it for lunch. I left barely remembering the food and still annoyed by the receipt, $19 for the veg lunch and a hot green tea! To wait in line while they scoop food from a pot onto your plate, seat yourself, then clean up after yourself does not justify $19. Plus the veg option is simply all the side dishes put together. There isn't an actual hot vegetation daily dish. I like the location and service is nice, but not going back. Much better high quality options nearby, ie Darwin on Ritch St.
author: LM H.

description:
Got a breakfast sandwich. $5, okay...

But dang it's pretty small.

And it's burned?

And it's stuck to the material it was wrapped in?!

Wish I had discovered this before I got to work, would've asked for a refund. Waste.
author: Cameron H.

description:
I'm a fan! I love that you can choose your own sides with the main dish. It almost feels like I'm at a cafeteria but the food is way better and higher quality. The service is also superb. 

When I came here, I told the guy that it was my first time here and he made it super simple for me to 'make my own picnic'. They were serving miso grazed chicken and a variety of side dishes. As a suggestion, the chicken is served with rice and some green beans. I was trying to be good so I skipped the rice and swapped it with an Asian cole slaw. They also recommended that I put some fish flakes on my cole slaw, and I'm glad I did because it mixed with the flavors really well. They also have some chili aioli that is the bomb. You can put as much as you want in your plate.

The menu changed day to day for lunch and dinner. I suggest checking it out on the website before you go in. And don't be afraid to ask for suggestions. They're super nice here.

You can also sit here or take your food to go. The ambience is really nice even though it's located on a busy street like 3rd.

Also, it's card only here. No cash!
author: Liezel D.

description:
Love the place but coffee is luke warm!!!

I love this place great addition to our neighborhood, it looks clean, the food is awesome the people are super friendly.

But: the coffee is cold. Ordered a latte this morning and when I finally took it over to my table it was quite cold. I think the tin cups they use don't keep the heat well, it's not the first time that this has happened. Hopefully they get new cups soon and heat the milk more. Awesome place otherwise - but coffee needs to be hot!!!
author: Hugh L.

description:
Picnic is extremely homey, with its decor of distressed wood, ceramic cups and chalkboard signs.  Unfortunately, the food reminds me of home too. For those of us whose mothers could not cook, picnic brings back reminders of leathery overlooked meats, over seasoned main courses supplemented by under seasoned side dishes.  I have come here numerous times with various coworkers and taste many valiant attempts at fancy recipes yielding very whatever tasting results. Forgetting to blanch the greens, not tenderizing the meat, not using enough spices...  These are all mistakes I expect to taste at home, not in a restaurant that changes well over $17 for lunch and a drink.  To top it off, the food was served room cold.  It reminds me perfectly of coming home late and half-microwaving leftovers for dinner, very homey.

Three coworkers and I came here for lunch, and not a single person cleared their main entree.  One person awkwardly claimed they were full, but I pointed out that the food was awful.  We all laughed and went to garaje next door for burgers.
author: Alice S.

description:
I think I'm in love with the concept more than anything else. First of all, "Picnic on Third," what a sweet and whimsical name, especially with South Park so close. 

With a plethora of lunch options catering to the tech crowd, I have to say the food scene in that area of 3rd Street is really difficult- there's Darwin, HRD, and Garaje all within walking distance! Picnic on Third's concept is fun, hipster, and very trendy. Their menus rotate every day and is always inspired by a global cuisine, which is really fun to just read about on their website You can pick any of their combinations - there's always at least one vegetarian option, or choose an entree and sides a la carte.

The cost is one of the bigger issues. While you can get a whole plate full of food, it will run you a good $14, which isn't really a good value for just lunch. Secondly, I think the food is really hit and miss depending on which cuisine/day you choose. I came to try Filipino food with adobo and I found it mostly bland. I got a lot of rice, which made me fairly full, but I didn't think it warranted a $14 price tag. 

It's really a pity because the space is fun, bright, and communal feeling, with lots of tables picnic-style. On the upside the people who work there seem passionate about the food, and you can get lots of sauces for free. Haven't tried the coffee but they do have a cafe option with pastries and coffee. They also serve breakfast sandwiches now!
author: Kate M.

description:
Came for lunch when they were serving Chicken Adobo with greens on fried rice. ($10.95 ish). As you get your plate, you could have chosen to add extra sides like a tea simmered hard boiled egg (+$2 or 3) or mango salsa ($3). The mango salsa went really well with the adobo, cutting through the fat and salt in a good way. Once you pay, you find an empty seat. Utensils are available at every table. Seating is slightly limited and better for parties of 2.

Chicken itself was tender and easily tore apart with the fork. Rice was lightly fried to just have a nice crisp edge which was rather tasty.

As other yelpers have mentioned, it's a bit on the pricier side but it reminds me of homecooking with strong flavors that makes you want more.
author: Cindy W.

description: Great staff. Awesome food. Delicious drinks. Cute place. What else could a girl want?
author: Briceyda L.

description: Been there twice, both times I liked how the food tasted, but it was cold. The sides are just sitting there at room temperature when they serve it. Why do you do this? We're not talking about a salad -- Brussel sprouts and squash are usually served hot. Way to waste otherwise tasty food.
author: Clément G.

description: My very favorite lunch spot in SOMA. Always fresh and delicious. Amazing produce, tasty meats, and incredible use of spices and seasonings. I love that each day the menu changes, so returning regularly is totally enjoyable!
author: Erin P.

description: Great for those who are looking for a hearty healthy meal! I was expecting some of the food to be a little more flavorful but overall awesome experience!
author: Keanna T.

description: Great food. Great prices. Great overall value.  Fruit isn't organic, but eh get the side of bacon instead. For $5 you get 5 pieces of brown sugar baked bacon. Uh, yum!
author: Sara S.

description: OMG this place & the folks there are awesome.  I got the Flank Steak and I have enough left for at least 3 more meal creations.  If you are have a special picnic I suggest you try Picnic. Fresh food, delicious plate combinations. The Pickles are homemade and I plan to pick up more. I cannot say how much I love this place.
author: Karolyn H.

description: Awesome lunch spot that never gets old because they rotate the menu daily, which gives a very home cooked taste to the food.  Today I ate here for the fifth time and will be back continually.  Nowhere else in the neighborhood gets me satisfied but still feeling light and healthy like this place.
author: Ryan C.

description: What's great about SF. You walk anywhere and find SPOTS to eat that are really good. Like this one on the way to the Giants game. Funky food. Just like the town.
author: Jonathan P.

description:
The most memorable part of this place is the very friendly and passionate staff. Every person seemed genuinely excited about the food they were serving, which was refreshing.

The food was very savory, and the entree with two sides was filling. There weren't very many options for entrees, one vegetarian and two regular ones, but they were all quiet good. The downside it is was overpriced. $13 for an entree with sides. The food is all already cooked, coming from large serving bowls. This made the steep price seem even steeper, considering for the same price you could have a cooked-to-order meal.

On the upside they serve alcohol, and had the Le Merle saison on tap, which is fantastic.
author: Michael S.
